response: def alan_partridge_stations(stations): required_stops = {'Rejection', 'Disappointment', 'Backstabbing Central', 'Shattered Dreams Parkway'} if required_stops.issubset(set(stations)): return 'Smell my cheese you mother!' else: return 'No, seriously, run. You will miss it.'

messages.content: Two boys decided to compete in text typing on the site "Key races". During the competition, they have to type a text consisting of s characters. The first participant types one character in v_1 milliseconds and has ping t_1 milliseconds. The second participant types one character in v_2 milliseconds and has ping t_2 milliseconds. If connection ping (delay) is t milliseconds, the competition passes for a participant as follows: Exactly after t milliseconds after the start of the competition the participant receives the text to be entered. Right after that he starts to type it. Exactly t milliseconds after he ends typing all the text, the site receives information about it. The winner is the participant whose information on the success comes earlier. If the information comes from both participants at the same time, it is considered that there is a draw. Given the length of the text and the information about participants, determine the result of the game. Write a function named `determine_typing_winner` to solve this problem. Here is an example input-output pair: assert determine_typing_winner(3, 3, 1, 1, 1) == Second assert determine_typing_winner(4, 5, 3, 1, 5) == Friendship Provide ONLY the function implementation in Python. Your solution must consist of high-quality and generally correct code. Put your solution between ... tags. If you think it would be impossible to satisfy the problem description or test case constraints, you may flag this issue to the user. To flag the issue, put your explanation in ... tags instead of providing code. ONLY flag if you are sure that the problem is impossible to satisfy. If you choose to flag the problem, do not provide a code solution.

response: def determine_typing_winner(s, v1, t1, v2, t2): # Calculate total time for the first participant # Time to receive the text: t1 milliseconds # Time to type the text: s * v1 milliseconds # Time to send the result: t1 milliseconds total_time_first = 2 * t1 + s * v1 # Calculate total time for the second participant # Time to receive the text: t2 milliseconds # Time to type the text: s * v2 milliseconds # Time to send the result: t2 milliseconds total_time_second = 2 * t2 + s * v2 if total_time_first < total_time_second: return "First" elif total_time_second < total_time_first: return "Second" else: return "Friendship"

messages.content: A team of three programmers is going to play a contest. The contest consists of n problems, numbered from 1 to n. Each problem is printed on a separate sheet of paper. The participants have decided to divide the problem statements into three parts: the first programmer took some prefix of the statements (some number of first paper sheets), the third contestant took some suffix of the statements (some number of last paper sheets), and the second contestant took all remaining problems. But something went wrong — the statements were printed in the wrong order, so the contestants have received the problems in some random order. The first contestant has received problems a_{1, 1}, a_{1, 2}, ..., a_{1, k_1}. The second one has received problems a_{2, 1}, a_{2, 2}, ..., a_{2, k_2}. The third one has received all remaining problems (a_{3, 1}, a_{3, 2}, ..., a_{3, k_3}). The contestants don't want to play the contest before they redistribute the statements. They want to redistribute them so that the first contestant receives some prefix of the problemset, the third contestant receives some suffix of the problemset, and the second contestant receives all the remaining problems. During one move, some contestant may give one of their problems to other contestant. What is the minimum number of moves required to redistribute the problems? It is possible that after redistribution some participant (or even two of them) will not have any problems. Write a function named `min_moves_to_redistribute` to solve this problem. response: def min_moves_to_redistribute(received1, received2, received3): # Combine all received problems into a single list to analyze combined = received1 + received2 + received3 # Total number of problems n = len(combined) # Convert the problem IDs received by each participant into sets for quick lookup set1 = set(received1) set2 = set(received2) set3 = set(received3) # The target is to partition the original sequence of problems into three parts: # prefix (for participant 1), middle (for participant 2), suffix (for participant 3) # # For each possible partition point: # prefix end at position i (0-based), suffix start at position j # with 0 <= i <= n, i <= j <= n # # The middle segment is from i to j-1 # # For each such partition, compute: # - Problems currently in participant 1's received list that are outside the prefix (needs to be given to participant 1) # - Problems in participant 2's list outside the middle segment # - Problems in participant 3's list outside the suffix segment # # Since problem IDs can be scattered, we need to evaluate minimal moves. # To facilitate fast set membership checks, map positions of each problem problem_positions = {} for idx, prob in enumerate(combined): problem_positions[prob] = idx min_moves = float('inf') # Iterate over all possible partitions for i in range(n + 1): # prefix ends at i-1 for j in range(i, n + 1): # suffix starts at j # Assign problems to middle segment # Problems in prefix: indices 0..i-1 # Problems in suffix: indices j..n-1 # Problems in middle: indices i..j-1 prefix_indices = set(range(i)) suffix_indices = set(range(j, n)) middle_indices = set(range(i, j)) # Count how many of participant's received problems are outside their target segment moves1 = sum(1 for prob in received1 if problem_positions[prob] not in prefix_indices) moves2 = sum(1 for prob in received2 if problem_positions[prob] not in middle_indices) moves3 = sum(1 for prob in received3 if problem_positions[prob] not in suffix_indices) total_moves = moves1 + moves2 + moves3 if total_moves < min_moves: min_moves = total_moves return min_moves

messages.content: You are given an array $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$. You can remove at most one subsegment from it. The remaining elements should be pairwise distinct. In other words, at most one time you can choose two integers $l$ and $r$ ($1 \leq l \leq r \leq n$) and delete integers $a_l, a_{l+1}, \ldots, a_r$ from the array. Remaining elements should be pairwise distinct. Find the minimum size of the subsegment you need to remove to make all remaining elements distinct. response: def min_subsegment_to_remove(a): n = len(a) max_unique_prefix = 0 seen = set() # Find the largest prefix with all distinct elements for i in range(n): if a[i] not in seen: seen.add(a[i]) max_unique_prefix = i + 1 else: break min_subsegment = n - max_unique_prefix # Initial answer: remove suffix after prefix seen_suffix = set() j = n - 1 # Expand suffix from the end, adding elements not in prefix for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1): if a[i] not in seen: seen_suffix.add(a[i]) # try to adjust the prefix to minimize removal while j >= 0 and a[j] != a[i]: j -= 1 # Now, a[j] == a[i] min_subsegment = min(min_subsegment, i - j + 1) else: # Already in prefix set, no need to expand further pass # Also check for cases where removing just a small middle segment is optimal # Initialize two pointers left = 0 seen_in_window = set() for right in range(n): # Skip duplicates in the window while a[right] in seen_in_window: seen_in_window.remove(a[left]) left += 1 seen_in_window.add(a[right]) # Update the minimum segment to remove min_subsegment = min(min_subsegment, right - left + 1) return min_subsegment

Otherwise, return False. Write a function as the solution for this problem. This kata looks simple, but it might not be easy. Write a function named `is_in_middle` to solve this problem. Here is an example input-output pair: assert is_in_middle("AabcBBB") == False assert is_in_middle("AAabcBB") == True Provide ONLY the function implementation in Python. response: def is_in_middle(s): target = "abc" index = s.find(target) while index != -1: left_len = index right_len = len(s) - (index + len(target)) if abs(left_len - right_len) <= 1: return True index = s.find(target, index + 1) return False

messages.content: Once upon a time, a CodeWarrior, after reading a discussion on what can be the plural, took a look at this page and discovered that more than 1 "kind of plural" may exist. For example Sursurunga Language distinguishes 5 types of numbers: singular (1 thing), dual (2 things), 'trial' or 'lesser paucal' (3 or 4), 'greater paucal' (more than 4) and plural (many). In this kata, you'll have to handle only four types of numbers: - singular: 0 or 1 thing - dual: 2 things - paucal: 3 to 9 things - plural: more than 9 things To add some flavor the number-marker will not be added in same places: - singular, no marker : `1 cat` - dual, prefixed "bu" : `2 cats -> 2 bucat` - paucal, suffixed "zo" : `4 cats -> 4 catzo` - plural, "circumfixed ga" : `100 cats -> 100 gacatga` As you all ("hawk eyes") have seen, the final `s` of english plural disappears. ( btw these markers, of course, have absolutely nothing to do with true sursurunga language, we're just talking about "pig"-sursurunga with pig as pig in "pig latin" ) ## Your Job . . . . . . if you accept it, will be to write a `sursurungal` function which get a `string` as argument and returns this string with words in it eventually converted to their "pig-sursurunga number type". If a `number` ( ie 1 or more digit ) + a `space` + a `word` ( letters ) are found then the word should be converted. Each group of `number+space+word` found in the string should be evaluated. You may assume at least 1 `number+space+word` group will be provided. Beware `s` of english plural should be removed, not ending `s` of some singular words ( eg "kiss" ) Write a function named `sursurungal` to solve this problem. Here is an example input-output pair: assert sursurungal('He has 5 books and 2 pens') == 'He has 5 bookzo and 2 bupen' assert sursurungal('There are 4 dogs') == 'There are 4 dogzo' assert sursurungal('1 cat is here') == '1 cat is here' assert sursurungal('I saw 100 birds') == 'I saw 100 gabirdga' assert sursurungal('15 cars are parked') == '15 gacarga are parked' Provide ONLY the function implementation in Python. Your solution must consist of high-quality and generally correct code. Put your solution between ... tags. If you think it would be impossible to satisfy the problem description or test case constraints, you may flag this issue to the user. response: def sursurungal(s): import re def convert_word(match): number = int(match.group(1)) word = match.group(2) base_word = word # Remove trailing 's' if word is plural (more than 1 and ends with 's') if number != 1 and word.endswith('s'): word = word[:-1] if number == 0 or number == 1: # singular: no marker return f"{number} {word}" elif number == 2: # dual: prefixed "bu" return f"{number} bu{word}" elif 3 <= number <= 9: # paucal: suffixed "zo" return f"{number} {word}zo" elif number > 9: # plural: circumfixed "ga" (before and after) return f"{number} ga{word}ga" else: # fallback (should not occur): return original return f"{number} {word}" # Pattern to match number + space + word pattern = re.compile(r'(\d+)\s+([a-zA-Z]+)') result = pattern.sub(convert_word, s) return result

response: def find_deletion_order(n, p_c_list): from collections import defaultdict, deque # Initialize data structures parents = [p for p, c in p_c_list] c_flags = [c for p, c in p_c_list] # Build the tree adjacency list (children for each node) children = [[] for _ in range(n)] root = -1 for i in range(n): p = parents[i] if p == -1: root = i else: children[p].append(i) # For each node, keep track of its children # Also, identify non-root nodes that could be candidate for deletion # Conditions for deletion: # - Not the root # - Does not respect parent (c_i == 1) # - None of its children respect it (i.e., all children have c_i == 1) # We need to process nodes in order of smallest number satisfying criteria # Let's use a min-heap to manage candidates import heapq # Initialize a min-heap with candidates heap = [] # Function to check if node is candidate for deletion def is_candidate(i): if i == root: return False if c_flags[i] != 1: return False p = parents[i] if c_flags[p] != 1: return False # All children of i must have c_i == 1 for ch in children[i]: if c_flags[ch] == 0: return False return True # Build initial candidate heap for i in range(n): if is_candidate(i): heapq.heappush(heap, i) result = [] # Keep track of whether the node has been deleted deleted = [False]*n while heap: v = heapq.heappop(heap) if deleted[v]: continue # Re-validate candidate because the tree might have changed if not is_candidate(v): continue # Delete node v deleted[v] = True result.append(v + 1) # Using 1-based indexing in output p = parents[v] # Reconnect v's children to v's parent for ch in children[v]: if not deleted[ch]: parents[ch] = p # After reconnection, check if ch now is candidate if is_candidate(ch): heapq.heappush(heap, ch) # Mark v's children as now connected directly to v's parent if p != -1: children[p].extend(children[v]) # Clear v's children to avoid double processing children[v] = [] return result

messages.content: Ronny the robot is watching someone perform the Cups and Balls magic trick. The magician has one ball and three cups, he shows Ronny which cup he hides the ball under (b), he then mixes all the cups around by performing multiple two-cup switches (arr). Ronny can record the switches but can't work out where the ball is. Write a programme to help him do this. Rules: - There will only ever be three cups. - Only two cups will be swapped at a time. - The cups and their switches will be refered to by their index in a row of three, beginning at one. So [[1,2]] means the cup at position one, is swapped with the cup at position two. - Arr will be an array of integers 1 - 3 organised in pairs. - There won't be any empty sub-arrays. - If arr is just an empty array b should be returned. Write a function named `cup_and_balls` to solve this problem. response: def cup_and_balls(b, arr): # If no swaps are performed, return the initial position of the ball if not arr: return b # Initialize the current position of the ball current_position = b for move in arr: # Each move is a pair of cups being swapped if current_position == move[0]: current_position = move[1] elif current_position == move[1]: current_position = move[0] # If the current position is not involved in the swap, it stays the same return current_position

response: def min_array_length(a): # Use a stack to simulate the process efficiently. stack = [] for element in a: if stack and stack[-1][0] == element: # Found a pair of neighboring equal elements count, total_count = stack[-1] # Merge: remove the top and insert the combined element # It has value = element + 1 after merging # The total count represents consecutive equal elements processed so far # We need to determine if merging reduces the overall length # For that, treat current pairing as one merge operation # So, update the top element to represent the merged block # Since the top was (element, count), after merge: # new_element_value = element + 1 # count = total_count + 1 # But instead, since the stack approach merges blocks, it's better to think in terms of the counts # We replace the top with a new block of the merged value # We can achieve this by popping and pushing a combined block # But to handle multiple consecutive merges, we need a recursive or iterative approach # # Let's proceed step-by-step: # Remove the top block stack.pop() # Check if the new block's value equals the top of the stack new_value = element + 1 # Now, if the top of the stack has the same value as new_value, we can merge again if stack and stack[-1][0] == new_value: # Merge with previous prev_value, prev_count = stack.pop() # Increase the count of the previous block stack.append((new_value, prev_count + 1)) else: # Else, push a new block stack.append((new_value, 1)) else: # No pair to merge, push current element stack.append((element, 1)) # After processing all elements, sum counts to get remaining length return sum(count for _, count in stack)

messages.content: Prior to having fancy iPhones, teenagers would wear out their thumbs sending SMS messages on candybar-shaped feature phones with 3x4 numeric keypads. ------- ------- ------- | | | ABC | | DEF | | 1 | | 2 | | 3 | ------- ------- ------- ------- ------- ------- | GHI | | JKL | | MNO | | 4 | | 5 | | 6 | ------- ------- ------- ------- ------- ------- |PQRS | | TUV | | WXYZ| | 7 | | 8 | | 9 | ------- ------- ------- ------- ------- ------- | | |space| | | | * | | 0 | | # | ------- ------- ------- Prior to the development of T9 (predictive text entry) systems, the method to type words was called "multi-tap" and involved pressing a button repeatedly to cycle through the possible values. For example, to type a letter "R" you would press the 7 key three times (as the screen display for the current character cycles through P->Q->R->S->7). A character is "locked in" once the user presses a different key or pauses for a short period of time (thus, no extra button presses are required beyond what is needed for each letter individually). The zero key handles spaces, with one press of the key producing a space and two presses producing a zero. In order to send the message "WHERE DO U WANT 2 MEET L8R" a teen would have to actually do 47 button presses. No wonder they abbreviated. For this assignment, write a module that can calculate the amount of button presses required for any phrase. Punctuation can be ignored for this exercise. Likewise, you can assume the phone doesn't distinguish between upper/lowercase characters (but you should allow your module to accept input in either for convenience). Hint: While it wouldn't take too long to hard code the amount of keypresses for all 26 letters by hand, try to avoid doing so! (Imagine you work at a phone manufacturer who might be testing out different keyboard layouts, and you want to be able to test new ones rapidly.) Write a function named `presses` to solve this problem. Here is an example input-output pair: assert presses('WHERE DO U WANT 2 MEET L8R') == 47 assert presses('ABC') == 6 assert presses('R') == 3 assert presses('HELLO') == 13 assert presses('0') == 2 Provide ONLY the function implementation in Python. response: def presses(phrase): # Mapping each character to the number of presses needed: # The keys and their respective letters: keypad = { '1': '', # No letters for 1 key '2': 'ABC', # 2 -> A(1), B(2), C(3) '3': 'DEF', # 3 -> D(1), E(2), F(3) '4': 'GHI', # 4 -> G(1), H(2), I(3) '5': 'JKL', # 5 -> J(1), K(2), L(3) '6': 'MNO', # 6 -> M(1), N(2), O(3) '7': 'PQRS', # 7 -> P(1), Q(2), R(3), S(4) '8': 'TUV', # 8 -> T(1), U(2), V(3) '9': 'WXYZ', # 9 -> W(1), X(2), Y(3), Z(4) '0': ' ', # 0 -> space (1), zero (2) '*': '', # No letter mapping, not used '#': '' # No letter mapping, not used } # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its number of presses letter_to_presses = {} for key, letters in keypad.items(): if letters: for index, letter in enumerate(letters): # number of presses = position in string + 1 letter_to_presses[letter] = index + 1 total_presses = 0 # Process each character in the input phrase for ch in phrase: # Convert to uppercase to match our mapping c = ch.upper() if c in letter_to_presses: total_presses += letter_to_presses[c] elif c == '0': # For '0', two presses: '0' and 'space' (which is on '0' key) total_presses += 2 elif c == ' ': # space handled as pressing '0' once total_presses += 1 # Ignore characters not in mapping (punctuation, etc.) return total_presses

response: def symmetric_difference(M, N): return sorted(set(M).symmetric_difference(set(N)))

messages.content: A common problem in number theory is to find x given a such that: a * x = 1 mod [n] Then x is called the inverse of a modulo n. Your goal is to code a function inverseMod wich take a and n as parameters and return x. You may be interested by these pages: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modular_multiplicative_inverse http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extended_Euclidean_algorithm a and n should be co-prime to have a solution, if it is not the case, you should return None (Python), nil (Ruby) or null (Javascript). a and n will be positive integers. The problem can easily be generalised to negative integer with some sign changes so we won't deal with them. Write a function named `inverseMod` to solve this problem. Here is an example input-output pair: assert inverseMod(7, 13) == 2 assert inverseMod(2, 5) == 3 assert inverseMod(3, 11) == 4 assert inverseMod(5, 7) == 3 Provide ONLY the function implementation in Python. Your solution must consist of high-quality and generally correct code. Put your solution between ... tags. response: def inverseMod(a, n): # Extended Euclidean Algorithm to find inverses def extended_gcd(x, y): if y == 0: return (x, 1, 0) gcd, x1, y1 = extended_gcd(y, x % y) return (gcd, y1, x1 - (x // y) * y1) gcd, x, _ = extended_gcd(a, n) # If a and n are not coprime, inverse doesn't exist if gcd != 1: return None # Ensure the inverse is positive return x % n

response: def max_problems_before_party(n, k): """ Calculates the maximum number of problems Limak can solve in the contest before the party, considering the time constraints. Args: n (int): Total number of problems. k (int): Time (in minutes) Limak needs to get to the party from his house. Returns: int: Maximum number of problems Limak can solve before leaving for the party. """ # Total contest duration in minutes (from 20:00 to midnight) total_contest_time = 4 * 60 # 240 minutes # Time Limak has for solving problems before leaving for the party available_time = total_contest_time - k total_time_spent = 0 max_problems = 0 for i in range(1, n + 1): problem_time = 5 * i if total_time_spent + problem_time <= available_time: total_time_spent += problem_time max_problems += 1 else: break return max_problems

messages.content: For every good kata idea there seem to be quite a few bad ones! In this kata you need to check the provided 2 dimensional array (x) for good ideas 'good' and bad ideas 'bad'. If there are one or two good ideas, return 'Publish!', if there are more than 2 return 'I smell a series!'. If there are no good ideas, as is often the case, return 'Fail!'. The sub arrays may not be the same length. The solution should be case insensitive (ie good, GOOD and gOOd all count as a good idea). All inputs may not be strings. Write a function named `well` to solve this problem. Here is an example input-output pair: assert well([[1, 2, 3], ['bad', 'bad', 'bad']]) == Fail! assert well([['good', 'bad', 'bad', 'bad', 'bad', 'good', 'bad', 'bad', 'good']]) == I smell a series! assert well([['good'], ['bad', 'bad', 'bad']]) == Publish! assert well([['GOOD', 'bad', 'bad', 'bad', 'bad', 'GOOD']]) == Publish! assert well([['good', 'bad', 'bad', 'bad', 'bad']]) == Publish! assert well([['bad', 'bad', 'bad']]) == Fail! response: def well(x): # Initialize count of good ideas good_count = 0 for subarray in x: for item in subarray: # Only process strings if isinstance(item, str): if item.lower() == 'good': good_count += 1 # Determine output based on good idea count if good_count == 0: return 'Fail!' elif good_count <= 2: return 'Publish!' else: return 'I smell a series!'
